findings.title: Unverified Remote Code Execution via curl|bash Installation
findings.description: The skill instructs the agent to download and execute a shell script directly from GitHub using 'curl | bash' without any cryptographic verification (no checksums, signatures, or hashes). This creates a critical supply chain attack vector where a compromised GitHub account, man-in-the-middle attack, or repository takeover could result in arbitrary code execution on the user's machine. The 'Quick install' method provides no security guarantees about the script's integrity.
findings.remediation: 1) Provide cryptographic checksums (SHA256) for the install script and verify before execution. 2) Use signed releases with GPG verification. 3) Pin to specific commit hashes instead of 'master' branch. 4) Include the install script content directly in the skill package for review. 5) Warn users about the security implications of remote script execution.

metadata.overall_assessment: This skill presents CRITICAL and HIGH severity security risks primarily related to supply chain security, resource exhaustion, and network exposure. The most severe issue is the unverified remote code execution via 'curl|bash' installation, which could allow arbitrary code execution if the source is compromised. The unbounded cryptocurrency mining operation poses availability risks through sustained CPU consumption without resource controls. Network exposure via hardcoded, unverified peer connections creates additional attack surface. The skill lacks essential security metadata (allowed-tools, license, compatibility) and provenance information, making trust assessment difficult. While the skill includes a reference to Clawdex security scanning, this does not mitigate the fundamental architectural security issues. The skill requires significant security hardening before it can be considered safe for automated agent use.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: Clear unverified remote code execution pattern. LLM analyzer correctly identified this as the primary threat. This is a well-known supply chain attack vector.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - requires only compromising the GitHub repository or performing MITM attack
metadata.meta_impact: Critical - arbitrary code execution with user privileges, potential system compromise

findings.title: Unbounded CPU Mining Without Resource Controls
findings.description: The skill instructs the agent to start cryptocurrency mining operations with no resource limits, monitoring, or automatic termination conditions. Mining is configured to run indefinitely in daemon mode with 'nice -n 19' priority adjustment but no CPU caps, time limits, or user confirmation for extended operation. The instruction 'scale up once you confirm everything is stable' encourages increasing resource consumption. This can lead to sustained CPU exhaustion, thermal issues, increased power consumption, and degraded system performance for other tasks.
findings.snippet:
nice -n 19 botcoind -daemon -mine -mineaddress="$ADDR" -minethreads=2
# Tip: start with -minethreads=2, then scale up once you confirm everything is stable.
findings.remediation: 1) Implement strict CPU usage caps (e.g., cpulimit, cgroups). 2) Add automatic termination after a defined time period or block count. 3) Require explicit user confirmation before starting mining. 4) Monitor system temperature and throttle/stop if thresholds are exceeded. 5) Provide clear warnings about resource consumption and electricity costs. 6) Add a maximum runtime parameter with default limits.

findings.title: Network Exposure via Hardcoded Seed Peers Without Verification
findings.description: The skill configures the agent to connect to hardcoded external IP addresses (95.111.227.14, 95.111.229.108, 161.97.83.147) on port 8433 without any verification of peer identity, certificate validation, or reputation checking. These connections are established automatically when the daemon starts. This creates risks of: 1) Connecting to malicious nodes that could serve invalid blockchain data, 2) Network traffic analysis and fingerprinting, 3) Potential exploitation if the P2P protocol has vulnerabilities, 4) No mechanism to verify these IPs are legitimate Botcoin network nodes.
findings.remediation: 1) Implement peer verification mechanisms (certificates, signatures). 2) Use DNS-based peer discovery instead of hardcoded IPs. 3) Provide peer reputation/trust scoring. 4) Allow users to review and approve peer connections. 5) Implement connection encryption and authentication. 6) Document the ownership and trustworthiness of seed nodes.
